subject: Re: [junit] Instantiated TestCase won't run tests

messageBody:
Yes, I have stopped because I have no other choice. Let me back up and explain
why I was trying this approach.

The Class:
I have a class that represents a table row in a database, lets call it
TableRowContainer. Instead of hardcoding many classes for each table in the
database, I have one class that can represent a row in any of them as long as
you pass in a table meta data class that explains what a row in a certain table
should be like.

The Test:
So to test this I write TableRowContainerTest. It uses a specific meta data
class, fakes some data for it, and then tests the public methods.

The Problem:
The only problem is that I don't think that it is sufficient just to have the
one hard coded meta data class, I want to test TableRowContainer with all of them.

Bad Solutions:
My first thought was to make a constructor in TableRowContainerTest that would
take a meta data class. In a separate class, I iterate through a list of these
meta data classes (which I get by looking through the file system). I construct
an instance of TableRowContainerTest with each piece of meta data, and run the
tests on each one. This doesn't work for a number of reasons that I have
previously mentioned.
It is not that I am wanting to pass data from one test to the other. It is that
TableRowContainerTest is setup to run it's tests in the context of a single type
of meta data. I need an outside class to construct an instance of
TableRowContainerTest with each meta data class and test it.
TableRowContainer is not itself setup to run through all of the meta data
classes mainly because it extends from EqualsHashCodeTest in the JUnit addons as
a way to test the equals and hashcode for free. in other words
TableRowContainerTest tests a single type of TableRowContainer. But I have many
that I would like to construct and check.

Good Solution:
I still don't see one.
I guess that it would be possible to sublcass TableRowContainerTest for each
instance of the meta data that I would otherwise construct an instance around.
But this is a lot of extra classes for no reason other than to get around a
limitation in JUnit.
I could also have a static variable that I repeatedly update to the new meta
data, and then run the tests. But this could get into some tricky threading
issues. But again I am not sure how I would update the variable and run the
tests, and get the TestResults to come out appropriately.

Is it so wrong to want to instantiate a test with some parameters and
automatically run the tests on it? I completely feel like I am missing
something here. Of course I am new to Unit Testing. It was trivially easy
until I came across this problem. Now it feels like I am fighting with JUnit,
and I know that I must not be thinking about this right. I can't find any
information on this type of problem. Parameterized TestCase is close, but I
don't want to override runTest(). I want the reflective base functionality to
run all methods named test* automatically, and for the results to show up
appropriately.

I appreciate the reply. I could really use some guidance on this if anyone has
anything to add.
Thanks,
Clay


>
> junityahoo@... wrote:
> >
> > So I write my first TestCase class. Lets call it MyTestCase. It works
> > great by
> > itself. It fakes some data that it will need, then runs through some
> > tests to
> > make sure everything works right. Great!
> >
> > Now what I want to do is instantiate MyTestCase from another TestCase
> > and have
> > it run through the tests.
>
> Stop!
>
> Don't do this. If you want to share data between tests, then make that
> data globally available from another resource, such as a file, a global
> variable, a database, whatever works.
>
> Do /not/ run tests from within other tests. You won't get the results
> you want, anyway.
